title: (x) Trivial Pursuit logo script - custom {Mike Y}
content:
Does anyone know the font used in this edition of Trivial Pursuit? Thanks

[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trivial\_Pursuit](http://web.archive.org/web/20150125063523/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trivial_Pursuit "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trivial\_Pursuit")
author: dl

comments.content: As it's a logo, this could very well be custom designed.
The current logo looks different, but originally they used [Balmoral](http://web.archive.org/web/20150125063523/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/balmoral/).

Here’s a better sample:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150125063523im_/http:/typophile.com/files/tp_4510.png)

For comparison: [Balmoral](http://web.archive.org/web/20150125063523/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=balmoral&site=d&sample_text=Trivial%20Pursuit&sample_size=96)

I think Yves is right.

Here's the old logo:

[http://hubpages.com/hub/Trivial-Pursuit-How-trivial-can-we-get](http://web.archive.org/web/20150125063523/http:/hubpages.com/hub/Trivial-Pursuit-How-trivial-can-we-get "http://hubpages.com/hub/Trivial-Pursuit-How-trivial-can-we-get")

It looks like they've been using the newer logo for while.

You can see that the new logo is hand-drawn, because at the larger size it's obvious that the i's and u's are not identical. The 's' is not really a script style letter either. Otherwise this resembles a simplified, thickened [Edwardian Script](http://web.archive.org/web/20150125063523/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/itc-edwardian-script/).

- Mike Yanega
